intro: Braya humilis subsp. maccallae, commonly known as the MacCall's bladderwort, is a small, mat-forming flowering plant native to arid regions of Australia. It belongs to the family Brassicaceae, which includes many economically important crops and weeds. The plant is characterized by its rosette of narrow, fleshy leaves and small, white or pink flowers that bloom in early spring. It is adapted to survive in dry, sandy soils and can enter dormancy during periods of drought. Its unique morphology and ecological niche make it an interesting subject for botanical study.
